ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right Tympanic Membrane Perforation (Barotrauma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of popping sound and otalgia during flight descent, mild conductive hearing loss, and flat tympanogram with large ear canal volume (4.2 mL).

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and determine type/degree of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To evaluate middle ear function and check for tympanic membrane perforation.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation reveals a mild conductive hearing loss in the right ear, consistent with the reported barotrauma. Tympanometry in the right ear shows a large ear canal volume, confirming a tympanic membrane perforation. The left ear presents with normal hearing sensitivity and middle ear function. Speech recognition is excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear mild conductive loss (250-2000 Hz) rising to normal, PTA 28 dB HL. Left ear normal limits, PTA 5 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear SRT 28 dB HL, WRS 96%. Left ear SRT 5 dB HL, WRS 100%.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear Type B (flat) with large ear canal volume (4.2 mL), consistent with perforation. Left ear Type A (normal), volume 1.2 mL.

proposed_items: Medical management to monitor perforation healing
Tympanoplasty if perforation does not heal
Use of hearing protection in noise
counseling_actions: Explanation of barotrauma and resulting tympanic membrane perforation
Water precautions (keep ear dry) to prevent infection

escalation.rationale_short: For evaluation of the tympanic membrane perforation and determination of surgical necessity if healing does not occur.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor healing of the tympanic membrane and hearing status.
